title: How to Paint Cast Iron

steps.headline: Put on goggles, gloves, and a mask before you start.
steps.description: Stripping the rust and any remaining paint off cast iron will send paint and metal fragments into the air. Protect yourself by covering your eyes and wearing a respirator or similar facemask. Prevent cuts by wearing thick work gloves. Wearing long sleeves and pants will help as well. You might rub against a rough part of metal and cut yourself. Make sure you wear old clothes as well. Sanding and painting metal is a dirty job.

steps.headline: Lay the iron piece on a sheet in a well-ventilated area.
steps.description: Always take precautions to protect yourself and your belongings. Lay down a drop cloth in a well-ventilated area, preferably outdoors. Then lay the piece on top of the cloth so you don't make a mess while working. If you're working indoors, take steps to ventilate the area. Open all nearby windows as widely as you can. If you have one, use a window-mounted box fan to pull fumes out of the room. If you're in a garage, leave the door open while you work. If you’re painting something that’s fixed down like a railing, lay sheets and drop cloths around the whole work area to avoid making a mess.

steps.headline: Scrape surfaces with a metal scraper to remove flaking paint and rust.
steps.description: Any leftover paint and rust on the iron’s surface will prevent new paint from adhering properly. Scrape back and forth several times with  in each spot  a scraper until loose pieces rub off. Don’t miss any spots. If you leave paint or rust behind, the new coat of paint will flake off. The iron won’t be entirely smooth after you scrape. This step removes flaking paint and rust. Subsequent steps will smooth out the surface. The noise from this scraping might be unpleasant. If you get the “nails on a chalkboard” feeling from scraping the iron, try wearing earplugs to help with the noise. If you're working on a new piece of iron without any rust or paint, then just clean the entire surface with mineral spirits before painting.

steps.headline: Use a wire brush to remove paint and rust from curved surfaces.
steps.description: If the iron piece you’re working on has designs or curves, like on a fence, a metal scraper won’t work. For curved portions, take a wire brush and use the same motions you used with the scraper. Scrub it until loose rust and paint come off. Be thorough when scrubbing hard to reach areas. If you miss any spots, your new paint won’t stick properly. If you’ve scrubbed with a scraper and a wire brush and the rust still won’t come off, try using a powered grinder to strip any remaining rust.

steps.headline: Sand the entire surface with 150-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: With the extra paint and outer rust layers gone, you can now smooth the iron’s surface. Sand the entire piece with 150-grit sandpaper. Make sure you get inside any curves or shapes in the iron so the whole surface is smooth. Keep your goggles and gloves on because sanding can send small fragments of rust and metal into the air. For a piece of iron with a lot of curves, you may prefer a sanding sponge because it’s more flexible. Use a medium grit and cover every surface of the iron the same as you would with sandpaper.

steps.headline: Wipe the piece with mineral spirits to remove dust and residue.
steps.description: Start by dampening a clean rag with some mineral spirits. Then rub the rag all over the iron’s surface. Re-wet the rag if you have to, especially if you’re working on a large piece of iron. You don’t have to rub hard. The rag should pick up any loose remnants without much scrubbing. A can of mineral spirits is available from any hardware store. It is also handy for cleaning your paint brushes and washing paint off your hands. Don’t use water to clean dust off the metal. This could cause rusting.

steps.headline: Select an oil-based primer designed for metal surfaces.
steps.description: Oil-based paints and primers adhere to metal better than water-based products. This is especially important for outdoor metal because oil-based paint resists the elements much better. The two primary options for primer are roll-on and spray. Roll-on primer is applied with a roller and brush, just like paint. It takes longer to apply than spray primer, but it's easier to control and you don't risk making a mess if there is wind. Spray-on primer from a can is a faster option that you can use if you're shorter on time. Make sure you’re in a well-ventilated area and wearing a mask whenever you use spray primer and paint. Also be careful applying spray primer outside if it's windy. A sudden gust could send paint everywhere. Whether you choose spray or roll-on primer, make sure it’s designed for metal application. The product label should state this. Ask a hardware store employee for help if you can’t find the right product.

steps.headline: Pour your roll-on primer into a paint tray.
steps.description: If you're using roll-on primer, you apply it the same way as you'd apply paint. Open the can and pour some into a paint tray. Then dip a paint roller in and wet it with some primer. Wipe the roller on the side of the pan a few times before you start applying it to prevent dripping.

steps.headline: Roll an even coat of primer onto the metal’s whole surface.
steps.description: After dipping the roller into the primer, use smooth strokes to apply it to the metal. Use an up-and-down motion to spread an even coat onto the iron's surface. Touch up areas you can’t reach with a brush. If there are any curves or corners on the piece of metal, you probably won’t be able to reach every spot with a roller. In this case, brush the primer onto these spots.

steps.headline: Apply spray-on primer by keeping it at least 10 in (25 cm) from the iron.
steps.description: Start by shaking the can well. Then keep the can at least 10 inches (25 cm) from the iron and begin spraying. Spray from several different directions for an even coat. Continue spraying until the metal's whole surface is covered. Take extra steps to cover anything nearby with a sheet. Pay attention to the weather as well. If it's getting windy, take a break until the wind dies down. Remember to wear goggles and a mask when using spray primer.

steps.headline: Let the primer dry for at least 2-4 hours.
steps.description: The length of time your primer takes to dry depends on several factors. Spray-on primer dries faster than rolled-on primer, and should take about 2 hours. Rolled-on primer should take at least 4. If it is humid out, each one will take longer. Monitor the primer to see when it dries. Lightly touch the surface to check if it’s still sticky or wet. If not, the primer is dry enough for painting.

steps.headline: Select an oil-based paint designed for metal surfaces.
steps.description: The same rules as primer apply for paint. Use an oil-based product that is designed for metal. You have the same option between using roll-on or spray paint. You don't have to use the same application method for primer and paint. For example, if you used spray primer but thought it made a mess, you can switch to roll-on paint. Similarly, if you used roll-on primer and thought it took too long, you can switch to spray paint.

steps.headline: Apply the first coat after the primer dries.
steps.description: If you're using roll-on paint, open the can and pour some into a paint tray. Then wet your roller and cover the entire piece of metal in an even coat. Use a brush to get any curves or grooves that the roller can’t reach into. If you use spray paint, do the work in a well-ventilated area, preferably outdoors. Wear face and eye protection, and cover everything nearby with a sheet. Keep the spray can moving and don't hover it in one place. This could cause dripping and runs. Don't pour the paint into a tray that still has primer in it. Either use a different tray or clean out the one you used for primer.

steps.headline: Add a second coat after the first coat dries.
steps.description: The first coat will take about 24 hours to dry and possibly more. It depends on the type of paint and environmental conditions. Monitor the paint and don’t start painting until the first coat is dry. When the paint doesn’t feel sticky anymore, you can add the second coat. Use the same techniques with the roller and touching up with a brush if there are spots you can’t reach. The same rules apply for spray paint. Wait until the first coat is completely dry, then spray on the second coat. Add an additional coat if the iron color still shows through the paint. A third coat will provide a more vibrant color.

steps.headline: Allow at least 24 hours for the paint to cure.
steps.description: Once the final coat is applied, it takes at least a full day for the paint to cure fully. Leave the iron piece alone and let the paint dry. Don't touch or use the piece while you're waiting. After 24 hours, the paint should be cured and you can move the piece to a new location.

After 24 hours, the paint should be cured and you can move the piece to a new location.
